para.sentence: \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize I}} – \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize VI}} can be written as a Hamiltonian system \frac{\mathrm{d}q}{\mathrm{d}z}=\frac{\partial\mathrm{H}}{\partial p},\frac{\mathrm{d}p}{\mathrm{d}z}=-\frac{\partial\mathrm{H}}{\partial q}, for suitable (non-autonomous) Hamiltonian functions \mathrm{H}(q,p,z).
The Hamiltonian for \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize I}} is \mathrm{H}_{\mbox{\scriptsize I}}(q,p,z)=\tfrac{1}{2}p^{2}-2q^{3}-zq, and so q^{\prime}=p, p^{\prime}=6q^{2}+z.
Then q=w satisfies \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize I}}.
The function \sigma=\mathrm{H}_{\mbox{\scriptsize I}}(q,p,z), defined by (32.6.2) satisfies \left(\sigma^{\prime\prime}\right)^{2}+4\left(\sigma^{\prime}\right)^{3}+2z \sigma^{\prime}-2\sigma=0.
Conversely, if \sigma is a solution of (32.6.6), then q=-\sigma^{\prime}, p=-\sigma^{\prime\prime}, are solutions of (32.6.3) and (32.6.4).

The Hamiltonian for \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize II}} is \mathrm{H}_{\mbox{\scriptsize II}}(q,p,z)=\tfrac{1}{2}p^{2}-(q^{2}+\tfrac{1}{2 }z)p-(\alpha+\tfrac{1}{2})q, and so q^{\prime}=p-q^{2}-\tfrac{1}{2}z, p^{\prime}=2qp+\alpha+\tfrac{1}{2}.
Then q=w satisfies \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize II}} and p satisfies pp^{\prime\prime}=\tfrac{1}{2}(p^{\prime})^{2}+2p^{3}-zp^{2}-\tfrac{1}{2}( \alpha+\tfrac{1}{2})^{2}.
The function \sigma(z)=\mathrm{H}_{\mbox{\scriptsize II}}(q,p,z) defined by ( 32.6.9)satisfies
\left(\sigma^{\prime\prime}\right)^{2}+4\left(\sigma^{\prime}\right)^{3}+2 \sigma^{\prime}\left(z\sigma^{\prime}-\sigma\right)=\tfrac{1}{4}(\alpha+\tfrac {1}{2})^{2}.
Conversely, if \sigma(z) is a solution of (32.6.13), then q=\ifrac{(4\sigma^{\prime\prime}+2\alpha+1)}{(8\sigma^{\prime})}, p=-2\sigma^{\prime}, are solutions of (32.6.10) and (32.6.11).

The Hamiltonian for \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize III}} is z\mathrm{H}_{\mbox{\scriptsize III}}(q,p,z)=q^{2}p^{2}-{\left(\kappa_{\infty} zq^{2}+(2\theta_{0}+1)q-\kappa_{0}z\right)p}+\kappa_{\infty}(\theta_{0}+\theta _{\infty})zq, and so zq^{\prime}=2q^{2}p-\kappa_{\infty}zq^{2}-(2\theta_{0}+1)q+\kappa_{0}z, , zp^{\prime}=-2qp^{2}+2\kappa_{\infty}zqp+(2\theta_{0}+1)p-\kappa_{\infty}( \theta_{0}+\theta_{\infty})z.
Then q=w satisfies \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize III}} with (\alpha,\beta,\gamma,\delta)=\left(-2\kappa_{\infty}\theta_{\infty},2\kappa_{0 }(\theta_{0}+1),\kappa_{\infty}^{2},-\kappa_{0}^{2}\right).
The function \sigma=z\mathrm{H}_{\mbox{\scriptsize III}}(q,p,z)+pq+\theta_{0}^{2}-\tfrac{1} {2}\kappa_{0}\kappa_{\infty}z^{2} defined by (32.6.16)satisfies

(z\sigma^{\prime\prime}-\sigma^{\prime})^{2}+2\left((\sigma^{\prime})^{2}- \kappa_{0}^{2}\kappa_{\infty}^{2}z^{2}\right)(z\sigma^{\prime}-2\sigma)+8 \kappa_{0}\kappa_{\infty}\theta_{0}\theta_{\infty}z\sigma^{\prime}=4\kappa_{0} ^{2}\kappa_{\infty}^{2}(\theta_{0}^{2}+\theta_{\infty}^{2})z^{2}.

Conversely, if \sigma is a solution of (32.6.21), then q=\frac{\kappa_{0}\left(z\sigma^{\prime\prime}-(2\theta_{0}+1)\sigma^{\prime}+ 2\kappa_{0}\kappa_{\infty}\theta_{\infty}z\right)}{\kappa_{0}^{2}\kappa_{ \infty}^{2}z^{2}-(\sigma^{\prime})^{2}}, p=\ifrac{(\sigma^{\prime}+\kappa_{0}\kappa_{\infty}z)}{(2\kappa_{0})}, are solutions of (32.6.17) and (32.6.18).

The Hamiltonian for \mbox{P}^{\prime}_{\mbox{\scriptsize III}} (§32.2(iii)) is \zeta\mathrm{H}_{\mbox{\scriptsize III}}(q,p,\zeta)=q^{2}p^{2}-\left(\eta_{ \infty}q^{2}+\theta_{0}q-\eta_{0}\zeta\right)p+\tfrac{1}{2}\eta_{\infty}( \theta_{0}+\theta_{\infty})q, and so \zeta q^{\prime}=2q^{2}p-\eta_{\infty}q^{2}-\theta_{0}q+\eta_{0}\zeta, \zeta p^{\prime}=-2qp^{2}+2\eta_{\infty}qp+\theta_{0}p-\tfrac{1}{2}\eta_{ \infty}(\theta_{0}+\theta_{1}).
Then q=u satisfies \mbox{P}^{\prime}_{\mbox{\scriptsize III}} with (\alpha,\beta,\gamma,\delta)=\left(-4\eta_{\infty}\theta_{\infty},4\eta_{0}( \theta_{0}+1),4\eta_{\infty}^{2},-4\eta_{0}^{2}\right).
The function \sigma=\zeta\mathrm{H}_{\mbox{\scriptsize III}}(q,p,\zeta)+\tfrac{1}{4}\theta_ {0}^{2}-\tfrac{1}{2}\eta_{0}\eta_{\infty}\zeta defined by (32.6.24)satisfies

\zeta^{2}(\sigma^{\prime\prime})^{2}+\left(4(\sigma^{\prime})^{2}-\eta_{0}^{2} \eta_{\infty}^{2}\right)(\zeta\sigma^{\prime}-\sigma)+\eta_{0}\eta_{\infty} \theta_{0}\theta_{\infty}\sigma^{\prime}=\tfrac{1}{4}\eta_{0}^{2}\eta_{\infty} ^{2}(\theta_{0}^{2}+\theta_{\infty}^{2}).

Conversely, if \sigma is a solution of (32.6.29), then q=\frac{\eta_{0}\left(\zeta\sigma^{\prime\prime}-2\theta_{0}\sigma^{\prime}+ \eta_{0}\eta_{\infty}\theta_{\infty}\right)}{\eta_{0}^{2}\eta_{\infty}^{2}-4( \sigma^{\prime})^{2}}, p=\ifrac{(2\sigma^{\prime}+\eta_{0}\eta_{\infty}\zeta)}{(2\eta_{0})}, are solutions of (32.6.25) and (32.6.26).

The Hamiltonian for \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize III}} with \gamma=0 is z\mathrm{H}_{\mbox{\scriptsize III}}(q,p,z)=q^{2}p^{2}+(\theta q-\kappa_{0}z)p -\kappa_{\infty}zq, and so zq^{\prime}=2q^{2}p+\theta q-\kappa_{0}z, zp^{\prime}=-2qp^{2}-\theta p+\kappa_{\infty}z.
Then q=w satisfies \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize III}} with (\alpha,\beta,\gamma,\delta)=\left(2\kappa_{\infty},\kappa_{0}(\theta-1),0,- \kappa_{0}^{2}\right).
The function \sigma=z\mathrm{H}_{\mbox{\scriptsize III}}(q,p,z)+pq+\tfrac{1}{4}(\theta+1)^{2} defined by (32.6.32)satisfies

(z\sigma^{\prime\prime}-\sigma^{\prime})^{2}+2(\sigma^{\prime})^{2}(z\sigma^{ \prime}-2\sigma)-4\kappa_{0}\kappa_{\infty}(\theta+1)\theta_{\infty}z\sigma^{ \prime}=4\kappa_{0}^{2}\kappa_{\infty}^{2}z^{2}.

Conversely, if \sigma is a solution of (32.6.37), then q=\ifrac{\kappa_{0}\left(z\sigma^{\prime\prime}-\theta\sigma^{\prime}+2\kappa_ {0}\kappa_{\infty}z\right)}{(\sigma^{\prime})^{2}}, p=\ifrac{\sigma^{\prime}}{(2\kappa_{0})}, are solutions of (32.6.33) and (32.6.34).
For Hamiltonian structure for \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize IV}} see Jimbo and Miwa (1981),Okamoto (1986); also Forrester and Witte (2001).
For Hamiltonian structure for \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize V}} see Jimbo and Miwa (1981),Okamoto (1987b); also Forrester and Witte (2002).
For Hamiltonian structure for \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize VI}} see Jimbo and Miwa (1981) andOkamoto (1987a); also Forrester and Witte (2004).
